data.text:
The literary news cycle concentrated on Puffin Books’ bowdlerizing of Roald Dahl’s great children’s books at the beginning of 2023. Language from Roald Dahl’s books was changed to reflect the latest sensitivities of our current era. Forbes reported on the publication of a new set of Dahl children’s books.

“Words like ‘fat’ have been trimmed; ‘ugly’ has been excised.”

“Nor should it matter that Dahl was a bit vile in his own eccentric way. Many of the best artists and writers and musicians are, after all.”

Authors such as Salman Rushdie and organizations like Pen America have decried the impact of changing the words in an author’s legacy books after his death, per the cited Forbes article.

Roald Dahl was no angel but this is absurd censorship. Puffin Books and the Dahl estate should be ashamed. — Salman Rushdie

I agree that the language of art should not be modified, but should be contextualized, for the modern reader. Roald Dahl’s treatment of children’s stories is exempt from the glitter wash treatment where the story is all benign and happy. Like Grimm’s Fairy Tales, the stories include punishment and villains.
